						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Mahatma Gandhi</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Gandhi" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_(disambiguation)" title="Gandhi (disambiguation)">Gandhi (disambiguation)</a>.</div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Good_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Good article (page does not exist)">Template:Good article</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox person (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox person</a>
<b>Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-hns&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-hns (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-hns</a>; 2 October 1869&#160;– 30 January 1948) was the preeminent leader of <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian nationalism</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Raj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Raj (page does not exist)">British-ruled India</a>. Employing <a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">nonviolent</a> <a href="/wiki/Civil_disobedience" title="Civil disobedience">civil disobedience</a>, Gandhi led India to independence and inspired movements for civil rights and freedom across the world. The <a href="/wiki/Honorific" title="Honorific">honorific</a> <b>Mahatma</b> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "high-souled", "venerable"<sup id="cite_ref-McGregor1993_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGregor1993-1">[1]</a></sup>)—applied to him first in 1914 in South Africa,<sup id="cite_ref-rajmohan_gandhi_p172_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rajmohan_gandhi_p172-2">[2]</a></sup>—is now used worldwide. He is also called <b>Bapu</b> (<a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>: endearment for "father",<sup id="cite_ref-McAllister1982_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McAllister1982-3">[3]</a></sup> "papa"<sup id="cite_ref-McAllister1982_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McAllister1982-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Eck2003_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eck2003-4">[4]</a></sup>) in India.
</p><p>Born and raised in a Hindu, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bania_(caste)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bania (caste) (page does not exist)">merchant caste</a>, family in coastal <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western India (page does not exist)">western India</a>, and trained in law at the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Temple" title="Inner Temple">Inner Temple</a>, London, Gandhi first employed nonviolent civil disobedience as an expatriate lawyer in South Africa, in the resident Indian community's struggle for civil rights. After his return to India in 1915, he set about organising peasants, farmers, and urban labourers to protest against excessive land-tax and discrimination. Assuming leadership of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> in 1921, Gandhi led nationwide campaigns for easing poverty, expanding women's rights, building religious and ethnic amity, ending <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">untouchability</a>, but above all for achieving <i><a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">Swaraj</a></i> or self-rule.
</p><p>Gandhi famously led Indians in challenging the British-imposed salt tax with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/wiki/Salt_March" title="Salt March">Dandi Salt March</a> in 1930, and later in calling for the British to <i><a href="/wiki/Quit_India" title="Quit India" class="mw-redirect">Quit India</a></i> in 1942. He was imprisoned for many years, upon many occasions, in both South Africa and India. Gandhi attempted to practise nonviolence and truth in all situations, and advocated that others do the same. He lived modestly in a <a href="/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram" title="Sabarmati Ashram">self-sufficient residential community</a> and wore the traditional Indian <i><a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a></i> and shawl, woven with yarn hand spun on a <i><a href="/wiki/Charkha" title="Charkha" class="mw-redirect">charkha</a></i>. He ate simple vegetarian food, and also undertook long <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_fasts_undertaken_by_Mahatma_Gandhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of fasts undertaken by Mahatma Gandhi (page does not exist)">fasts</a> as means of both self-purification and social protest.
</p><p>Gandhi's vision of a free India based on religious pluralism, however, was challenged in the early 1940s by a new Muslim nationalism which was demanding a separate Muslim homeland carved out of India.<sup id="cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2007-page1-5">[5]</a></sup> Eventually, in August 1947, Britain granted independence, but the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Empire" title="British Indian Empire" class="mw-redirect">British Indian Empire</a><sup id="cite_ref-Khan2007-page1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2007-page1-5">[5]</a></sup> was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partitioned</a> into two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion (page does not exist)">dominions</a>, a Hindu-majority <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion_of_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion of India (page does not exist)">India</a> and Muslim <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion_of_Pakistan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion of Pakistan (page does not exist)">Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-6">[6]</a></sup> As many displaced Hindus, Muslims, and <a href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikhs</a> made their way to their new lands, religious violence broke out, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_region" title="Punjab region">Punjab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>. Eschewing the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Independence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Independence (page does not exist)">official celebration of independence</a> in Delhi, Gandhi visited the affected areas, attempting to provide solace. In the months following, he undertook several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fast_unto_death&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fast unto death (page does not exist)">fasts unto death</a> to promote religious harmony. The last of these, undertaken on 12 January 1948 at age 78,<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-7">[7]</a></sup> also had the indirect goal of pressuring India to pay out some cash assets owed to Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-7">[7]</a></sup> Some Indians thought Gandhi was too accommodating.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991-p380_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-p380-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CushRobinson2008_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CushRobinson2008-8">[8]</a></sup> Among them was <a href="/wiki/Nathuram_Godse" title="Nathuram Godse">Nathuram Godse</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hindu_nationalism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hindu nationalism (page does not exist)">Hindu nationalist</a>, who assassinated Gandhi on 30 January 1948 by firing three bullets into his chest at point-blank range.<sup id="cite_ref-CushRobinson2008_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CushRobinson2008-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi is commonly, though not officially,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> considered the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Father_of_the_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Father of the Nation (page does not exist)">Father of the Nation</a><sup id="cite_ref-Markovits2006_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Markovits2006-10">[10]</a></sup> in India. His birthday, 2 October, is commemorated there as <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Jayanti" title="Gandhi Jayanti">Gandhi Jayanti</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Holidays_in_India" title="Holidays in India" class="mw-redirect">national holiday</a>, and world-wide as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Day_of_Non-Violence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Day of Non-Violence (page does not exist)">International Day of Nonviolence</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_background">Early life and background</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Young_Gandhi.jpg" title="File:Young Gandhi.jpg">File:Young Gandhi.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in his earliest known photo, aged 7, c. 1876</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi was born Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, or "Mohan", on 2 October 1869 to Karamchand Gandhi (called Kaba) and his wife Putlibai<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> in a many-roomed, three-story house in <a href="/wiki/Porbandar" title="Porbandar">Porbandar</a><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> which is the present day <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kirti_Mandir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kirti Mandir (page does not exist)">Kirti Mandir</a> – a temple of peace.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Gandhi’s birthplace is in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kathiawar_Peninsula&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kathiawar Peninsula (page does not exist)">Kathiawar Peninsula</a> (also known as <a href="/wiki/Saurashtra_(region)" title="Saurashtra (region)">Saurashtra</a>), a region today part of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a> state in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> but then within the <a href="/wiki/Bombay_Presidency" title="Bombay Presidency">Bombay Presidency</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British India (page does not exist)">British India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> Described by Gandhi as "a lover of his clan, truthful, brave and generous",<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> his father was the <a href="/wiki/Dewan" title="Dewan">Diwan</a> (chief minister) of <a href="/wiki/Porbandar" title="Porbandar">Porbandar</a> at the time of Gandhi’s birth,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> but later became the Diwan of <a href="/wiki/Rajkot" title="Rajkot">Rajkot</a> in 1876.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Gandhi's grandfather Uttamchand Gandhi was also the Diwan of Porbandar.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> His mother, Putlibai, who was from a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pranami&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pranami (page does not exist)">Pranami</a> <a href="/wiki/Vaishnava" title="Vaishnava" class="mw-redirect">Vaishnava</a> family,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> was Karamchand's fourth wife, the first three wives having apparently died in childbirth.<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Indian classics, especially the stories of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shravan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shravan (page does not exist)">Shravana</a> and king <a href="/wiki/Harishchandra" title="Harishchandra">Harishchandra</a>, had a great impact on Gandhi in his childhood. In his autobiography, he admits that they left an indelible impression on his mind. He writes: "It haunted me and I must have acted Harishchandra to myself times without number." Gandhi's early self-identification with truth and love as supreme values is traceable to these epic characters.<sup id="cite_ref-Sorokin2002_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sorokin2002-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RudolphRudolph1983_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RudolphRudolph1983-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1883, the 13-year-old Mohandas was married to 14-year-old <a href="/wiki/Kasturba_Gandhi" title="Kasturba Gandhi">Kasturbai Makhanji</a> (her first name was usually shortened to "Kasturba", and affectionately to "Ba") in an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arranged_marriage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arranged marriage (page does not exist)">arranged</a> <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">child marriage</a>, according to the custom of the region.<sup id="cite_ref-Mohanty2011_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mohanty2011-26">[26]</a></sup> In the process, he lost a year at school.<sup id="cite_ref-Childhood_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Childhood-27">[27]</a></sup> Recalling the day of their marriage, he once said, "As we didn't know much about marriage, for us it meant only wearing new clothes, eating sweets and playing with relatives." However, as was prevailing tradition, the adolescent bride was to spend much time at her parents' house, and away from her husband.<sup id="cite_ref-Husband_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Husband-28">[28]</a></sup> In 1885, when Gandhi was 15, the couple's first child was born, but survived only a few days. Gandhi's father, Karamchand Gandhi, had also died earlier that year.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> The religious background was eclectic. Gandhi's father was <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modh (page does not exist)">Modh</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baniya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baniya (page does not exist)">Baniya</a><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> and his mother was from Pranami Vaishnava family. Religious figures were frequent visitors to the home.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mohandas and Kasturba had four more children, all sons: <a href="/wiki/Harilal_Gandhi" title="Harilal Gandhi">Harilal</a>, born in 1888; <a href="/wiki/Manilal_Gandhi" title="Manilal Gandhi">Manilal</a>, born in 1892; <a href="/wiki/Ramdas_Gandhi" title="Ramdas Gandhi">Ramdas</a>, born in 1897; and <a href="/wiki/Devdas_Gandhi" title="Devdas Gandhi">Devdas</a>, born in 1900.<sup id="cite_ref-Mohanty2011_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mohanty2011-26">[26]</a></sup> At his middle school in Porbandar and high school in <a href="/wiki/Rajkot" title="Rajkot">Rajkot</a>, Gandhi remained a mediocre student. He shone neither in the classroom nor on the playing field. One of the terminal reports rated him as "good at English, fair in Arithmetic and weak in Geography; conduct very good, bad handwriting." He passed the <a href="/wiki/Matriculation" title="Matriculation">matriculation exam</a> at Samaldas College in <a href="/wiki/Bhavnagar" title="Bhavnagar">Bhavnagar</a>, Gujarat, with some difficulty. Gandhi's family wanted him to be a <a href="/wiki/Barrister" title="Barrister">barrister</a>, as it would increase the prospects of succeeding to his father's post.<sup id="cite_ref-Preparation_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Preparation-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="English_barrister">English barrister</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Kasturbhai_1902.jpg" title="File:Gandhi and Kasturbhai 1902.jpg">File:Gandhi and Kasturbhai 1902.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi and his wife <a href="/wiki/Kasturba_Gandhi" title="Kasturba Gandhi">Kasturba</a> (1902)</div></div></div>In 1888, Gandhi travelled to London, England, to study law at <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>, where he studied Indian law and <a href="/wiki/Jurisprudence" title="Jurisprudence">jurisprudence</a> and trained as a <a href="/wiki/Barrister" title="Barrister">barrister</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Temple" title="Inner Temple">Inner Temple</a>. His time in London was influenced by a vow he had made to his mother upon leaving India, in the presence of a Jain monk, to observe the precepts of abstinence from meat and alcohol as well as of promiscuity.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi2006a_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2006a-34">[34]</a></sup> Gandhi tried to adopt "English" customs, including taking dancing lessons. However, he could not appreciate the bland vegetarian food offered by his landlady and was frequently hungry until he found one of London's few vegetarian restaurants. Influenced by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Salt's</a> writing, he joined the <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a>, was elected to its executive committee,<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-35">[35]</a></sup> and started a local <a href="/wiki/Bayswater" title="Bayswater">Bayswater</a> chapter.<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup> Some of the vegetarians he met were members of the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>, which had been founded in 1875 to further universal brotherhood, and which was devoted to the study of <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist" class="mw-redirect">Buddhist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> literature. They encouraged Gandhi to join them in reading the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhagavad_Gita&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bhagavad Gita (page does not exist)">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> both in translation as well as in the original.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-35">[35]</a></sup> Not having shown interest in religion before, he became interested in religious thought.
<p>Gandhi was called to the bar in June 1891 and then left London for India, where he learned that his mother had died while he was in London and that his family had kept the news from him.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991_35-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-35">[35]</a></sup> His attempts at establishing a law practice in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bombay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bombay (page does not exist)">Bombay</a> failed because he was too shy to speak up in court. He returned to Rajkot to make a modest living drafting petitions for litigants, but he was forced to close it when he ran foul of a British officer.<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brown1991_35-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1991-35">[35]</a></sup> In 1893, he accepted a year-long contract from Dada Abdulla &amp; Co., an Indian firm, to a post in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Colony_of_Natal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Colony of Natal (page does not exist)">Colony of Natal</a>, South Africa, then part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_rights_movement_in_South_Africa_.281893.E2.80.931914.29">Civil rights movement in South Africa (1893–1914)</span></h2>
<p>Gandhi was 24 when he arrived in South Africa<sup id="cite_ref-NHOA-193_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NHOA-193-36">[36]</a></sup> to work as a legal representative for the Muslim Indian Traders based in the city of Pretoria.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-37">[37]</a></sup> He spent 21 years in South Africa, where he developed his political views, ethics and political leadership skills. Guha argues that when he returned to India in 1914 he was proficient at public speaking, fund-raising, negotiations, media relations, and self-promotion.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_South-Africa.jpg" title="File:Gandhi South-Africa.jpg">File:Gandhi South-Africa.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi in South Africa (1895)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_South_Africans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian South Africans (page does not exist)">Indians in South Africa</a> were led by wealthy Muslims, who employed Gandhi as a lawyer, and by impoverished Hindu indentured labourers with very limited rights. Gandhi considered them all to be Indians, taking a lifetime view that "Indianness" transcended religion and caste. He believed he could bridge historic differences, especially regarding religion, and he took that belief back to India where he tried to implement it. The South African experience exposed handicaps to Gandhi that he had not known about. He realised he was out of contact with the enormous complexities of religious and cultural life in India, and believed he understood India by getting to know and leading Indians in South Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-Parekh2001_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Parekh2001-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>In South Africa, Gandhi faced the discrimination directed at all coloured people. He was thrown off a train at <a href="/wiki/Pietermaritzburg" title="Pietermaritzburg">Pietermaritzburg</a> after refusing to move from the first-class. He protested and was allowed on first class the next day.<sup id="cite_ref-.28Mahatma.29Fischer2002_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.28Mahatma.29Fischer2002-40">[40]</a></sup> Travelling farther on by stagecoach, he was beaten by a driver for refusing to move to make room for a European passenger.<sup id="cite_ref-Stagecoach_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stagecoach-41">[41]</a></sup> He suffered other hardships on the journey as well, including being barred from several hotels. In another incident, the magistrate of a <a href="/wiki/Durban" title="Durban">Durban</a> court ordered Gandhi to remove his turban, which he refused to do.<sup id="cite_ref-Turban_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turban-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>These events were a turning point in Gandhi's life and shaped his social activism and awakened him to social injustice. After witnessing racism, <a href="/wiki/Prejudice" title="Prejudice">prejudice</a> and injustice against Indians in South Africa, Gandhi began to question his place in society and his people's standing in the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allen2011_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allen2011-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi extended his original period of stay in South Africa to assist Indians in opposing a bill to deny them the right to vote. In regard to this bill Gandhi sent out a memorial to <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Chamberlain" title="Joseph Chamberlain">Joseph Chamberlain</a>, British Colonial Secretary, asking him to reconsider his position on this bill.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi-37">[37]</a></sup> Though unable to halt the bill's passage, his campaign was successful in drawing attention to the grievances of Indians in South Africa. He helped found the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Natal_Indian_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Natal Indian Congress (page does not exist)">Natal Indian Congress</a> in 1894,<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-.28Mahatma.29Fischer2002_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.28Mahatma.29Fischer2002-40">[40]</a></sup> and through this organisation, he moulded the Indian community of South Africa into a unified political force. In January 1897, when Gandhi landed in Durban, a mob of white settlers attacked him<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> and he escaped only through the efforts of the wife of the police superintendent. However, he refused to press charges against any member of the mob, stating it was one of his principles not to seek redress for a personal wrong in a court of law.<sup id="cite_ref-Tendulkar1951_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tendulkar1951-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1906, the <a href="/wiki/Transvaal_Colony" title="Transvaal Colony">Transvaal</a> government promulgated a new Act compelling registration of the colony's Indian population. At a mass protest meeting held in Johannesburg on 11 September that year, Gandhi adopted his still evolving methodology of <i>Satyagraha</i> (devotion to the truth), or nonviolent protest, for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-Rai2000_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rai2000-45">[45]</a></sup> He urged Indians to defy the new law and to suffer the punishments for doing so. The community adopted this plan, and during the ensuing seven-year struggle, thousands of Indians were jailed, flogged, or shot for striking, refusing to register, for burning their registration cards or engaging in other forms of nonviolent resistance. The government successfully repressed the Indian protesters, but the public outcry over the harsh treatment of peaceful Indian protesters by the South African government forced South African leader <a href="/wiki/Jan_Christiaan_Smuts" title="Jan Christiaan Smuts" class="mw-redirect">Jan Christiaan Smuts</a>, himself a philosopher, to negotiate a compromise with Gandhi. Gandhi's ideas took shape, and the concept of <i>Satyagraha</i> matured during this struggle.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhi_and_the_Africans">Gandhi and the Africans</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_suit.jpg" title="File:Gandhi suit.jpg">File:Gandhi suit.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi in South Africa (1909)</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi focused his attention on Indians while in South Africa and opposed the idea that Indians should be treated at the same level as native Africans while in South Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> He also stated that he believed "that the white race of South Africa should be the predominating race."<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> After several treatments he received from <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_South_African&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White South African (page does not exist)">Whites in South Africa</a>, Gandhi began to change his thinking and apparently increased his interest in politics.<sup id="cite_ref-Quinn2009_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Quinn2009-50">[50]</a></sup> White rule enforced strict segregation among all races and generated conflict between these communities. Bhana and Vahed argue that Gandhi, at first, shared racial notions prevalent of the times and that his experiences in jail sensitized him to the plight of South Africa's indigenous peoples.<sup id="cite_ref-BhanaVahed2005_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BhanaVahed2005-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Boer_war" title="Boer war" class="mw-redirect">Boer war</a> Gandhi volunteered in 1900 to form a group of ambulance drivers. He wanted to disprove the British idea that Hindus were not fit for "manly" activities involving danger and exertion. Gandhi raised eleven hundred Indian volunteers. They were trained and medically certified to serve on the front lines. At <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Spion_Kop" title="Battle of Spion Kop">Spion Kop</a> Gandhi and his bearers had to carry wounded soldiers for miles to a field hospital because the terrain was too rough for the ambulances. Gandhi was pleased when someone said that European ambulance corpsmen could not make the trip under the heat without food or water. General Redvers Buller mentioned the courage of the Indians in his dispatch. Gandhi and thirty-seven other Indians received the War Medal.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1906, when the British <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bambatha_Rebellion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bambatha Rebellion (page does not exist)">declared war</a> against the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zulu_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zulu Kingdom (page does not exist)">Zulu Kingdom</a> in Natal, Gandhi encouraged the British to recruit Indians.<sup id="cite_ref-Beene2010_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beene2010-53">[53]</a></sup> He argued that Indians should support the war efforts to legitimise their claims to full citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-Beene2010_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beene2010-53">[53]</a></sup> The British accepted Gandhi's offer to let a detachment of 20 Indians volunteer as a stretcher-bearer corps to treat wounded British soldiers. This corps was commanded by Gandhi and operated for less than two months.<sup id="cite_ref-Herman2010_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2010-54">[54]</a></sup> The experience taught him it was hopeless to directly challenge the overwhelming military power of the British army—he decided it could only be resisted in nonviolent fashion by the pure of heart.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi2006b_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2006b-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the black majority came to power in South Africa, Gandhi was proclaimed a national hero with numerous monuments.<sup id="cite_ref-Mbeki2006_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mbeki2006-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Struggle_for_Indian_Independence_.281915.E2.80.9347.29">Struggle for Indian Independence (1915–47)</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1915, Gandhi returned to India permanently. He brought an international reputation as a leading Indian nationalist, theorist and organiser. He joined the Indian National Congress and was introduced to Indian issues, politics and the Indian people primarily by <a href="/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale" title="Gopal Krishna Gokhale">Gopal Krishna Gokhale</a>. Gokhale was a key leader of the Congress Party best known for his restraint and moderation, and his insistence on working inside the system. Gandhi took Gokhale's liberal approach based on British Whiggish traditions and transformed it to make it look wholly Indian.<sup id="cite_ref-Whiggism_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whiggism-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi took leadership of Congress in 1920 and began a steady escalation of demands (with intermittent compromises or pauses) until on 26 January 1930 the Indian National Congress declared the independence of India. The British did not recognise that and more negotiations ensued, with Congress taking a role in provincial government in the late 1930s. Gandhi and Congress withdrew their support of the Raj when the Viceroy declared war on Germany in September 1939 without consulting anyone. Tensions escalated until Gandhi demanded immediate independence in 1942 and the British responded by imprisoning him and tens of thousands of Congress leaders for the duration. Meanwhile the Muslim League did cooperate with Britain and moved, against Gandhi's strong opposition, to demands for a totally separate Muslim state of Pakistan. In August 1947 the British partitioned the land, with India and Pakistan each achieving independence on terms that Gandhi disapproved.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Role_in_World_War_I">Role in World War I</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In April 1918, during the latter part of World War I, the <a href="/wiki/Frederic_Thesiger,_1st_Viscount_Chelmsford" title="Frederic Thesiger, 1st Viscount Chelmsford">Viceroy</a> invited Gandhi to a War Conference in Delhi.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Perhaps to show his support for the Empire and help his case for India's independence,<sup id="cite_ref-Recruiting_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Recruiting-60">[60]</a></sup> Gandhi agreed to actively recruit Indians for the war effort.<sup id="cite_ref-wikilivres.ca_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wikilivres.ca-61">[61]</a></sup> In contrast to the Zulu War of 1906 and the outbreak of World War I in 1914, when he recruited volunteers for the Ambulance Corps, this time Gandhi attempted to recruit combatants. In a June 1918 leaflet entitled "Appeal for Enlistment", Gandhi wrote "To bring about such a state of things we should have the ability to defend ourselves, that is, the ability to bear arms and to use them...If we want to learn the use of arms with the greatest possible despatch, it is our duty to enlist ourselves in the army."<sup id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks17b_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks17b-62">[62]</a></sup> He did, however, stipulate in a letter to the <a href="/wiki/John_Maffey,_1st_Baron_Rugby" title="John Maffey, 1st Baron Rugby">Viceroy's private secretary</a> that he "personally will not kill or injure anybody, friend or foe."<sup id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks17c_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks17c-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's war recruitment campaign brought into question his consistency on nonviolence. <a href="/wiki/Mahadev_Desai" title="Mahadev Desai">Gandhi's private secretary</a> noted that "The question of the consistency between his creed of 'Ahimsa' (nonviolence) and his recruiting campaign was raised not only then but has been discussed ever since."<sup id="cite_ref-wikilivres.ca_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wikilivres.ca-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Champaran_and_Kheda">Champaran and Kheda</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Kheda_1918.jpg" title="File:Gandhi Kheda 1918.jpg">File:Gandhi Kheda 1918.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi in 1918, at the time of the Kheda and Champaran Satyagrahas</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi's first major achievements came in 1918 with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Champaran_and_Kheda_Satyagraha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Champaran and Kheda Satyagraha (page does not exist)">Champaran and Kheda agitations</a> of Bihar and Gujarat. The Champaran agitation pitted the local peasantry against their largely British landlords who were backed by the local administration. The peasantry was forced to grow Indigo, a cash crop whose demand had been declining over two decades, and were forced to sell their crops to the planters at a fixed price. Unhappy with this, the peasantry appealed to Gandhi at his ashram in Ahmedabad. Pursuing a strategy of nonviolent protest, Gandhi took the administration by surprise and won concessions from the authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-Hardiman2001_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hardiman2001-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1918, <a href="/wiki/Kheda" title="Kheda">Kheda</a> was hit by floods and famine and the peasantry was demanding relief from taxes. Gandhi moved his headquarters to <a href="/wiki/Nadiad" title="Nadiad">Nadiad</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Laboratory_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Laboratory-65">[65]</a></sup> organising scores of supporters and fresh volunteers from the region, the most notable being <a href="/wiki/Vallabhbhai_Patel" title="Vallabhbhai Patel">Vallabhbhai Patel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi_Patel_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_Patel-66">[66]</a></sup> Using noncooperation as a technique, Gandhi initiated a signature campaign where peasants pledged non-payment of revenue even under the threat of confiscation of land. A social boycott of <i>mamlatdars</i> and <i>talatdars</i> (revenue officials within the district) accompanied the agitation. Gandhi worked hard to win public support for the agitation across the country. For five months, the administration refused but finally in end-May 1918, the Government gave way on important provisions and relaxed the conditions of payment of revenue tax until the famine ended. In Kheda, Vallabhbhai Patel represented the farmers in negotiations with the British, who suspended revenue collection and released all the prisoners.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown1974_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown1974-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Khilafat_movement">Khilafat movement</span></h3>
<p>In 1919 Gandhi, with his weak position in Congress, decided to broaden his base by increasing his appeal to Muslims. The opportunity came from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Khilafat_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khilafat movement (page does not exist)">Khilafat movement</a>, a worldwide protest by Muslims against the collapsing status of the <a href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliph</a>, the leader of their religion. The Ottoman Empire had lost the World War and was dismembered, as Muslims feared for the safety of the holy places and the prestige of their religion.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Although Gandhi did not originate the All-India Muslim Conference,<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> which directed the movement in India, he soon became its most prominent spokesman and attracted a strong base of Muslim support with local chapters in all Muslim centres in India.<sup id="cite_ref-Roberts1923_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts1923-70">[70]</a></sup> His success made him India's first national leader with a multicultural base and facilitated his rise to power within Congress, which had previously been unable to reach many Muslims. In 1920 Gandhi became a major leader in Congress.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> By the end of 1922 the Khilafat movement had collapsed.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi always fought against "communalism", which pitted Muslims against Hindus in politics, but he could not reverse the rapid growth of communalism after 1922. Deadly religious riots broke out in numerous cities, including 91 in U.P. (<a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>) alone.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> At the leadership level, the proportion of Muslims among delegates to Congress fell sharply, from 11% in 1921 to under 4% in 1923.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Noncooperation">Noncooperation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_spinning.jpg" title="File:Gandhi spinning.jpg">File:Gandhi spinning.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mahatma Gandhi spinning yarn, in the late 1920s</div></div></div>
<p>With Congress now behind him in 1920, Gandhi had the base to employ noncooperation, nonviolence and peaceful resistance as his "weapons" in the struggle against the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Raj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Raj (page does not exist)">British Raj</a>. His wide popularity among both Hindus and Muslims made his leadership possible; he even convinced the extreme faction of Muslims to support peaceful noncooperation.<sup id="cite_ref-Roberts1923_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts1923-70">[70]</a></sup> The spark that ignited a national protest was overwhelming anger at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jallianwala_Bagh_massacre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jallianwala Bagh massacre (page does not exist)">Jallianwala Bagh massacre</a> (or Amritsar massacre) of hundreds of peaceful civilians by British troops in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Punjab_(British_India)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Punjab (British India) (page does not exist)">Punjab</a>. Many Britons celebrated the action as needed to prevent another violent uprising similar to the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Rebellion of 1857</a>, an attitude that caused many Indian leaders to decide the Raj was controlled by their enemies. Gandhi criticised both the actions of the British Raj and the retaliatory violence of Indians. He authored the resolution offering condolences to British civilian victims and condemning the riots which, after initial opposition in the party, was accepted following Gandhi's emotional speech advocating his principle that all violence was evil and could not be justified.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the massacre and subsequent violence, Gandhi began to focus on winning complete self-government and control of all Indian government institutions, maturing soon into <i><a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">Swaraj</a></i> or complete individual, spiritual, political independence.<sup id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty2008_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty2008-78">[78]</a></sup> During this period, Gandhi claimed to be a "highly orthodox <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a>" and in January 1921 during a speech at a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir,_Vadtal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, Vadtal (page does not exist)">temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vadtal" title="Vadtal">Vadtal</a>, he spoke of the relevance of noncooperation to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hindu_Dharma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hindu Dharma (page does not exist)">Hindu Dharma</a>, "At this holy place, I declare, if you want to protect your 'Hindu Dharma', non-cooperation is first as well as the last lesson you must learn up.".<sup id="cite_ref-dh03_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dh03-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_home.jpg" title="File:Gandhi home.jpg">File:Gandhi home.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram" title="Sabarmati Ashram">Sabarmati Ashram</a>, Gandhi's home in Gujarat as seen in 2006.</div></div></div>
<p>In December 1921, Gandhi was invested with executive authority on behalf of the Indian National Congress. Under his leadership, the Congress was reorganised with a new constitution, with the goal of <i>Swaraj</i>. Membership in the party was opened to anyone prepared to pay a token fee. A hierarchy of committees was set up to improve discipline, transforming the party from an elite organisation to one of mass national appeal. Gandhi expanded his nonviolence platform to include the <a href="/wiki/Swadeshi_movement" title="Swadeshi movement"><i>swadeshi</i> policy</a>—the boycott of foreign-made goods, especially British goods. Linked to this was his advocacy that <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Khadi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khadi (page does not exist)">khadi</a></i> (homespun cloth) be worn by all Indians instead of British-made textiles. Gandhi exhorted Indian men and women, rich or poor, to spend time each day spinning <i>khadi</i> in support of the independence movement.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi even invented a small, portable spinning wheel that could be folded into the size of a small typewriter.<sup id="cite_ref-PopularScience1931_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopularScience1931-81">[81]</a></sup> This was a strategy to inculcate discipline and dedication to weeding out the unwilling and ambitious and to include women in the movement at a time when many thought that such activities were not respectable activities for women. In addition to boycotting British products, Gandhi urged the people to boycott British educational institutions and law courts, to resign from government employment, and to forsake <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_honours_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British honours system (page does not exist)">British titles and honours</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Shashi1996_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shashi1996-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Non-cooperation" enjoyed widespread appeal and success, increasing excitement and participation from all strata of Indian society. Yet, just as the movement reached its apex, it ended abruptly as a result of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chauri_Chaura_incident&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chauri Chaura incident (page does not exist)">violent clash in the town of Chauri Chaura</a>, Uttar Pradesh, in February 1922. Fearing that the movement was about to take a turn towards violence, and convinced that this would be the undoing of all his work, Gandhi called off the campaign of mass civil disobedience.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> This was the third time that Gandhi had called off a major campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-GreatSoulReview_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GreatSoulReview-84">[84]</a></sup> Gandhi was arrested on 10 March 1922, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years' imprisonment. He began his sentence on 18 March 1922. He was released in February 1924 for an <a href="/wiki/Appendicitis" title="Appendicitis">appendicitis</a> operation, having served only two years.<sup id="cite_ref-Datta2006_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Datta2006-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>Without Gandhi's unifying personality, the Indian National Congress began to splinter during his years in prison, splitting into two factions, one led by <a href="/wiki/Chitta_Ranjan_Das" title="Chitta Ranjan Das" class="mw-redirect">Chitta Ranjan Das</a> and <a href="/wiki/Motilal_Nehru" title="Motilal Nehru">Motilal Nehru</a> favouring party participation in the legislatures, and the other led by <a href="/wiki/Chakravarti_Rajagopalachari" title="Chakravarti Rajagopalachari" class="mw-redirect">Chakravarti Rajagopalachari</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sardar_Vallabhbhai_Patel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel (page does not exist)">Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel</a>, opposing this move. Furthermore, cooperation among Hindus and Muslims, which had been strong at the height of the nonviolence campaign, was breaking down. Gandhi attempted to bridge these differences through many means, including a three-week fast in the autumn of 1924, but with limited success.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> In this year, Gandhi was persuaded to preside over the Congress session to be held in <a href="/wiki/Belgaum" title="Belgaum">Belgaum</a>. Gandhi agreed to become president of the session on one condition: that Congressmen should take to wearing homespun khadi. In his long political career, this was the only time when he presided over a Congress session.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi.2C_the_forgotten_Mahatma_Belgaum_Congress_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi.2C_the_forgotten_Mahatma_Belgaum_Congress-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salt_Satyagraha_.28Salt_March.29">Salt Satyagraha (Salt March)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Salt_March.ogg" title="File:Salt March.ogg">File:Salt March.ogg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Original footage of Gandhi and his followers marching to Dandi in the Salt Satyagraha</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi stayed out of active politics and, as such, the limelight for most of the 1920s. He focused instead on resolving the wedge between the Swaraj Party and the Indian National Congress, and expanding initiatives against untouchability, alcoholism, ignorance and poverty. He returned to the fore in 1928. In the preceding year, the British government had appointed a new constitutional reform commission under Sir John Simon, which did not include any Indian as its member. The result was a boycott of the commission by Indian political parties. Gandhi pushed through a resolution at the Calcutta Congress in December 1928 calling on the British government to grant India <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion (page does not exist)">dominion</a> status or face a new campaign of noncooperation with complete independence for the country as its goal. Gandhi had not only moderated the views of younger men like <a href="/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose" title="Subhas Chandra Bose">Subhas Chandra Bose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a>, who sought a demand for immediate independence, but also reduced his own call to a one year wait, instead of two.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The British did not respond. On 31 December 1929, the flag of India was unfurled in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>. 26 January 1930 was celebrated as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independence_Day_(India)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independence Day (India) (page does not exist)">India's Independence Day</a> by the Indian National Congress meeting in Lahore. This day was commemorated by almost every other Indian organisation. Gandhi then launched a new Satyagraha against the tax on salt in March 1930. This was highlighted by the famous Salt March to Dandi from 12 March to 6 April, where he marched <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> from Ahmedabad to Dandi, Gujarat to make salt himself. Thousands of Indians joined him on this march to the sea. This campaign was one of his most successful at upsetting British hold on India; Britain responded by imprisoning over 60,000&#160;people.<sup id="cite_ref-Hatt2002_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hatt2002-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Women">Women</span></h4>
<p>Gandhi strongly favoured the emancipation of women, and he went so far as to say that "the women have come to look upon me as one of themselves." He opposed <i><a href="/wiki/Purdah" title="Purdah">purdah</a></i>, child marriage, <a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchability</a>, and the extreme oppression of Hindu widows, up to and including <i><a href="/wiki/Sati_(practice)" title="Sati (practice)">sati</a></i>. He especially recruited women to participate in the salt tax campaigns and the boycott of foreign products.<sup id="cite_ref-Norvell1997_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norvell1997-89">[89]</a></sup> Sarma concludes that Gandhi's success in enlisting women in his campaigns, including the salt tax campaign, anti-untouchability campaign and the peasant movement, gave many women a new self-confidence and dignity in the mainstream of Indian public life.<sup id="cite_ref-Sarma1994_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sarma1994-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhi_as_folk_hero">Gandhi as folk hero</span></h4>
<p>Congress in the 1920s appealed to peasants by portraying Gandhi as a sort of <a href="/wiki/Messiah" title="Messiah">messiah</a>, a strategy that succeeded in incorporating radical forces within the peasantry into the nonviolent resistance movement. In thousands of villages plays were performed that presented Gandhi as the reincarnation of earlier Indian nationalist leaders, or even as a demigod. The plays built support among illiterate peasants steeped in traditional Hindu culture. Similar messianic imagery appeared in popular songs and poems, and in Congress-sponsored religious pageants and celebrations. The result was that Gandhi became not only a folk hero but the Congress was widely seen in the villages as his sacred instrument.<sup id="cite_ref-Murali1985_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Murali1985-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Negotiations">Negotiations</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mahadev_Desai_and_Gandhi_2_1939.jpg" title="File:Mahadev Desai and Gandhi 2 1939.jpg">File:Mahadev Desai and Gandhi 2 1939.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mahadev_Desai" title="Mahadev Desai">Mahadev Desai</a> (left) reading out a letter to Gandhi from the <a href="/wiki/Viceroy" title="Viceroy">viceroy</a> at Birla House, Bombay, 7 April 1939</div></div></div>
<p>The government, represented by <a href="/wiki/E._F._L._Wood,_1st_Earl_of_Halifax" title="E. F. L. Wood, 1st Earl of Halifax">Lord Edward Irwin</a>, decided to negotiate with Gandhi. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhi%E2%80%93Irwin_Pact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhi–Irwin Pact (page does not exist)">Gandhi–Irwin Pact</a> was signed in March 1931. The British Government agreed to free all political prisoners, in return for the suspension of the civil disobedience movement. Also as a result of the pact, Gandhi was invited to attend the Round Table Conference in London as the sole representative of the Indian National Congress. The conference was a disappointment to Gandhi and the nationalists, because it focused on the Indian princes and Indian minorities rather than on a transfer of power. Lord Irwin's successor, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freeman_Freeman-Thomas,_1st_Marquess_of_Willingdon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon (page does not exist)">Lord Willingdon</a>, taking a hard line against nationalism, began a new campaign of controlling and subduing the nationalist movement. Gandhi was again arrested, and the government tried and failed to negate his influence by completely isolating him from his followers.<sup id="cite_ref-Herman2008_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Herman2008-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Untouchables">Untouchables</span></h3>
<p>In 1932, through the campaigning of the Dalit leader <a href="/wiki/B._R._Ambedkar" title="B. R. Ambedkar">B. R. Ambedkar</a>, the government granted untouchables separate electorates under the new constitution, known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Communal_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Communal Award (page does not exist)">Communal Award</a>. In protest, Gandhi embarked on a six-day fast on 20 September 1932, while he was imprisoned at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yerwada_Jail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yerwada Jail (page does not exist)">Yerwada Jail</a>, Pune.<sup id="cite_ref-yer_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yer-93">[93]</a></sup> The resulting public outcry successfully forced the government to adopt an equitable arrangement (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Poona_Pact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poona Pact (page does not exist)">Poona Pact</a>) through negotiations mediated by <a href="/wiki/Palwankar_Baloo" title="Palwankar Baloo">Palwankar Baloo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-yer_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yer-93">[93]</a></sup> This was the start of a new campaign by Gandhi to improve the lives of the untouchables, whom he named <a href="/wiki/Harijan" title="Harijan">Harijans</a>, the children of God.<sup id="cite_ref-Coward2003_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coward2003-94">[94]</a></sup> On 8 September 1931, Mahatma Gandhi who was sailing on <a href="/w/index.php?title=SS_Rajputana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SS Rajputana (page does not exist)">SS Rajputana</a>, to the second <a href="/wiki/Round_Table_Conferences_(India)" title="Round Table Conferences (India)">Round Table Conference</a> in London, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohandas_Karamchand_Gandhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (page does not exist)">Mahatma Gandhi</a> met <a href="/wiki/Meher_Baba" title="Meher Baba">Meher Baba</a> in his cabin on board the ship, and discussed issues of untouchables, politics, state Independence and spirituality<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 8 May 1933, Gandhi began a 21-day fast of self-purification and launched a one-year campaign to help the Harijan movement.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> This new campaign was not universally embraced within the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dalit_(outcaste)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dalit (outcaste) (page does not exist)">Dalit</a> community, as Ambedkar condemned Gandhi's use of the term <i>Harijans</i> as saying that Dalits were socially immature, and that privileged caste Indians played a paternalistic role. Ambedkar and his allies also felt Gandhi was undermining Dalit political rights. Gandhi had also refused to support the untouchables in 1924–25 when they were campaigning for the right to pray in temples. Because of Gandhi's actions, Ambedkar described him as "devious and untrustworthy".<sup id="cite_ref-GreatSoulReview_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GreatSoulReview-84">[84]</a></sup> Gandhi, although born into the <a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishya</a> caste, insisted that he was able to speak on behalf of Dalits, despite the presence of Dalit activists such as Ambedkar.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> Gandhi and Ambedkar often clashed because Ambedkar sought to remove the Dalits out of the Hindu community, while Gandhi tried to save Hinduism by exorcising untouchability. Ambedkar complained that Gandhi moved too slowly, while Hindu traditionalists said Gandhi was a dangerous radical who rejected scripture. Guha noted in 2012 that, "Ideologues have carried these old rivalries into the present, with the demonization of Gandhi now common among politicians who presume to speak in Ambedkar's name."<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Congress_politics">Congress politics</span></h3>
<p>In 1934 Gandhi resigned from Congress party membership. He did not disagree with the party's position but felt that if he resigned, his popularity with Indians would cease to stifle the party's membership, which actually varied, including communists, socialists, trade unionists, students, religious conservatives, and those with pro-business convictions, and that these various voices would get a chance to make themselves heard. Gandhi also wanted to avoid being a target for Raj propaganda by leading a party that had temporarily accepted political accommodation with the Raj.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Gandhi returned to active politics again in 1936, with the Nehru presidency and the Lucknow session of the Congress. Although Gandhi wanted a total focus on the task of winning independence and not speculation about India's future, he did not restrain the Congress from adopting socialism as its goal. Gandhi had a clash with Subhas Chandra Bose, who had been elected president in 1938, and who had previously expressed a lack of faith in nonviolence as a means of protest.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> Despite Gandhi's opposition, Bose won a second term as Congress President, against Gandhi's nominee, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhogaraju_Pattabhi_Sitaramayya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bhogaraju Pattabhi Sitaramayya (page does not exist)">Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya</a>; but left the Congress when the All-India leaders resigned en masse in protest of his abandonment of the principles introduced by Gandhi.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><sup id="cite_ref-Sarkar2006_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sarkar2006-100">[100]</a></sup> Gandhi declared that Sitaramayya's defeat was his defeat.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II_and_Quit_India">World War II and <i>Quit India</i></span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Nehru_1942.jpg" title="File:Gandhi and Nehru 1942.jpg">File:Gandhi and Nehru 1942.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi and Nehru in 1942</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi initially favoured offering "nonviolent moral support" to the British effort when <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> broke out in 1939, but the Congressional leaders were offended by the unilateral inclusion of India in the war without consultation of the people's representatives. All Congressmen resigned from office.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> After long deliberations, Gandhi declared that India could not be party to a war ostensibly being fought for democratic freedom while that freedom was denied to India itself. As the war progressed, Gandhi intensified his demand for independence, calling for the British to <i>Quit India</i> in a speech at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gowalia_Tank_Maidan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gowalia Tank Maidan (page does not exist)">Gowalia Tank Maidan</a>. This was Gandhi's and the Congress Party's most definitive revolt aimed at securing the British exit from India.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Gandhi was criticised by some Congress party members and other Indian political groups, both pro-British and anti-British. Some felt that not supporting Britain more in its struggle against Nazi Germany was unethical. Others felt that Gandhi's refusal for India to participate in the war was insufficient and more direct opposition should be taken, while Britain fought against Nazism, it continued to refuse to grant India Independence. <i>Quit India</i> became the most forceful movement in the history of the struggle, with mass arrests and violence on an unprecedented scale.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 1942, although still committed in his efforts to <i>"launch a nonviolent movement"</i>, Gandhi clarified that the movement would not be stopped by individual acts of violence, saying that the <i>"ordered anarchy"</i> of <i>"the present system of administration"</i> was <i>"worse than real anarchy."</i><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> He called on all Congressmen and Indians to maintain discipline via <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>, and <i>Karo ya maro</i> ("Do or die") in the cause of ultimate freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Jinnah_1944.jpg" title="File:Gandhi Jinnah 1944.jpg">File:Gandhi Jinnah 1944.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah (page does not exist)">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>, Bombay, 1944</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi and the entire Congress Working Committee were arrested in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bombay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bombay (page does not exist)">Bombay</a> by the British on 9 August 1942. Gandhi was held for two years in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aga_Khan_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aga Khan Palace (page does not exist)">Aga Khan Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a>. It was here that Gandhi suffered two terrible blows in his personal life. His 50-year old secretary Mahadev Desai died of a heart attack 6&#160;days later and his wife Kasturba died after 18 months imprisonment on 22 February 1944; six weeks later Gandhi suffered a severe <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> attack. He was released before the end of the war on 6 May 1944 because of his failing health and necessary surgery; the Raj did not want him to die in prison and enrage the nation. He came out of detention to an altered political scene—the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> for example, which a few years earlier had appeared marginal, "now occupied the centre of the political stage"<sup id="cite_ref-Lapping1989_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lapping1989-105">[105]</a></sup> and the topic of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah (page does not exist)">Jinnah</a>'s campaign for Pakistan was a major talking point. Gandhi met Jinnah in September 1944 in Bombay but Jinnah rejected, on the grounds that it fell short of a fully independent Pakistan, his proposal of the right of Muslim provinces to opt out of substantial parts of the forthcoming political union.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>While the leaders of Congress languished in jail, the other parties supported the war and gained organizational strength. Underground publications flailed at the ruthless suppression of Congress, but it had little control over events.<sup id="cite_ref-BhattacharyaStudies2001_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BhattacharyaStudies2001-108">[108]</a></sup> At the end of the war, the British gave clear indications that power would be transferred to Indian hands. At this point Gandhi called off the struggle, and around 100,000 political prisoners were released, including the Congress's leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Partition_and_independence.2C_1947">Partition and independence, 1947</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mountbattens_with_Gandhi_(IND_5298).jpg" title="File:Mountbattens with Gandhi (IND 5298).jpg">File:Mountbattens with Gandhi (IND 5298).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi with <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Louis Mountbatten</a>, Britain's last Viceroy of India, 1947</div></div></div>
<p>As a rule, Gandhi was opposed to the concept of <a href="/wiki/Partition_(law)" title="Partition (law)">partition</a> as it contradicted his vision of religious unity.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Concerning the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India to create Pakistan</a>, while the Indian National Congress and Gandhi called for the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a> to <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">quit India</a>, the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> passed a resolution for them to divide and quit, in 1943.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Gandhi suggested an agreement which required the Congress and Muslim League to cooperate and attain independence under a provisional government, thereafter, the question of partition could be resolved by a plebiscite in the districts with a Muslim majority.<sup id="cite_ref-.28Mahatma.29Jack1994_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.28Mahatma.29Jack1994-112">[112]</a></sup> When Jinnah called for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Direct_Action_Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Direct Action Day (page does not exist)">Direct Action</a>, on 16 August 1946, Gandhi was infuriated and personally visited the most riot-prone areas to stop the massacres.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> He made strong efforts to unite the Indian Hindus, Muslims, and Christians and struggled for the emancipation of the "<a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchables</a>" in Hindu society.<sup id="cite_ref-T.C3.B8nnesson_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T.C3.B8nnesson-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 14 and 15 August 1947 the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Independence_Act_1947" title="Indian Independence Act 1947">Indian Independence Act</a> was invoked. In border areas some 10–12 million people moved from one side to another and upwards of a half million were killed in communal riots pitting Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs against each other.<sup id="cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2006_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2006-115">[115]</a></sup> But for his teachings, the efforts of his followers, and his own presence, there perhaps could have been much more bloodshed during the partition, according to prominent Norwegian historian, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jens_Arup_Seip&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jens Arup Seip (page does not exist)">Jens Arup Seip</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Stanley_Wolpert" title="Stanley Wolpert">Stanley Wolpert</a> has argued, The "plan to carve up British India was never approved of or accepted by Gandhi...who realised too late that his closest comrades and disciples were more interested in power than principle, and that his own vision had long been clouded by the illusion that the struggle he led for India's independence was a nonviolent one."<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Assassination">Assassination</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MKGandhi_assassination_spot.jpg" title="File:MKGandhi assassination spot.jpg">File:MKGandhi assassination spot.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Memorial at the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birla_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birla House (page does not exist)">Birla House</a>, New Delhi, where <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohandas_Karamchand_Gandhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (page does not exist)">Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</a> was assassinated at 5:17 PM on 30 January 1948 on his way to a prayer meeting. Stylized footsteps are shown leading to the memorial.</div></div></div>
<p>Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi was assassinated in the garden of the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birla_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birla House (page does not exist)">Birla House</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Smriti" title="Gandhi Smriti">Gandhi Smriti</a>) at 5:17 PM on 30 January 1948. Accompanied by his grandnieces, Gandhi was on his way to address a prayer meeting, when his assassin, <a href="/wiki/Nathuram_Godse" title="Nathuram Godse">Nathuram Godse</a>, fired three bullets from a <a href="/wiki/Beretta" title="Beretta">Beretta</a> 9&#160;mm pistol into his chest at point-blank range.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi2007_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi2007-118">[118]</a></sup> Godse was a Hindu nationalist with links to the extremist <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha" class="mw-redirect">Hindu Mahasabha</a>, who held Gandhi guilty of favouring Pakistan and strongly opposed the doctrine of nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Godse and his co-conspirator were tried and executed in 1949. Gandhi's memorial (or <i>Samādhi</i>) at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raj_Ghat_and_other_memorials&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raj Ghat and other memorials (page does not exist)">Rāj Ghāt</a>, New Delhi, bears the epigraph "Hē Ram", (<a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>: <i>हे&#160;! राम</i> or, <i>He [[Rama|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IAST&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IAST (page does not exist)">Template:IAST</a>]]</i>), which may be translated as "Oh God". These are widely believed to be Gandhi's last words after he was shot, though the veracity of this statement has been disputed.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru addressed the nation through radio:<sup id="cite_ref-Singh2009_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Singh2009-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote>Friends and comrades, the light has gone out of our lives, and there is darkness everywhere, and I do not quite know what to tell you or how to say it. Our beloved leader, Bapu as we called him, the father of the nation, is no more. Perhaps I am wrong to say that; nevertheless, we will not see him again, as we have seen him for these many years, we will not run to him for advice or seek solace from him, and that is a terrible blow, not only for me, but for millions and millions in this country.—Jawaharlal Nehru's address to Gandhi<sup id="cite_ref-Jai1996_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jai1996-122">[122]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>Gandhi's death was mourned nationwide. Over two million people joined the five-mile long funeral procession that took over five hours to reach Raj Ghat from Birla house, where he was assassinated. Gandhi's body was transported on a weapons carrier, whose chassis was dismantled overnight to allow a high-floor to be installed so that people could catch a glimpse of his body. The engine of the vehicle was not used, instead four drag-ropes manned by 50 people each pulled the vehicle.<sup id="cite_ref-ie48_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ie48-123">[123]</a></sup> All Indian-owned establishments in London remained closed in mourning as thousands of people from all faiths and denominations and Indians from all over Britain converged at <a href="/w/index.php?title=India_House,_London&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="India House, London (page does not exist)">India House</a> in London.<sup id="cite_ref-ie48pg5_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ie48pg5-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>While India mourned and communal (inter-religious) violence escalated, there were calls for retaliation, and even an invasion of Pakistan by the Indian army. Nehru and Patel, the two strongest figures in the government and in Congress, had been pulling in opposite directions; the assassination pushed them together. They agreed the first objective must be to calm the hysteria.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> They called on Indians to honour Gandhi's memory and even more his ideals.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> They used the assassination to consolidate the authority of the new Indian state.
