The government made sure everyone knew the guilty party was not a Muslim. Congress tightly controlled the epic public displays of grief over a two-week period—the funeral, mortuary rituals and distribution of the martyr's ashes—as millions participated and hundreds of millions watched. The goal was to assert the power of the government and legitimise the Congress Party's control. This move built upon the massive outpouring of Hindu expressions of grief. The government suppressed the <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">RSS</a>, the Muslim National Guards, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Khaksars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Khaksars (page does not exist)">Khaksars</a>, with some 200,000 arrests. Gandhi's death and funeral linked the distant state with the Indian people and made more understood the need to suppress religious parties during the transition to independence for the Indian people.<sup id="cite_ref-Khan2011_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khan2011-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ashes">Ashes</span></h3>
<p>By Hindu tradition the ashes were to be spread on a river. Gandhi's ashes were poured into urns which were sent across India for memorial services.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Most were immersed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sangam_at_Allahabad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sangam at Allahabad (page does not exist)">Sangam at Allahabad</a> on 12 February 1948, but some were secretly taken away. In 1997, <a href="/wiki/Tushar_Gandhi" title="Tushar Gandhi">Tushar Gandhi</a> immersed the contents of one urn, found in a bank vault and reclaimed through the courts, at the Sangam at Allahabad.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian-2008-ashes_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-2008-ashes-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kumar2006_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kumar2006-130">[130]</a></sup> Some of Gandhi's ashes were scattered at the source of the Nile River near Jinja, Uganda, and a memorial plaque marks the event. On 30 January 2008, the contents of another urn were immersed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Girgaum_Chowpatty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Girgaum Chowpatty (page does not exist)">Girgaum Chowpatty</a>. Another urn is at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aga_Khan_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aga Khan Palace (page does not exist)">palace</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Aga_Khan" title="Aga Khan">Aga Khan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pune" title="Pune">Pune</a><sup id="cite_ref-Guardian-2008-ashes_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian-2008-ashes-129">[129]</a></sup> (where Gandhi had been imprisoned from 1942 to 1944) and another in the <a href="/wiki/Self-Realization_Fellowship_Lake_Shrine" title="Self-Realization Fellowship Lake Shrine">Self-Realization Fellowship Lake Shrine</a> in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-GWPM_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GWPM-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Principles.2C_practices_and_beliefs">Principles, practices and beliefs</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<i>Gandhism</i> designates the ideas and principles Gandhi promoted. Of central importance is nonviolent resistance. A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Gandhians&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Gandhians (page does not exist)">Gandhian</a> can mean either an individual who follows, or a specific philosophy which is attributed to, Gandhism.<sup id="cite_ref-Hardiman2001_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hardiman2001-64">[64]</a></sup> M.M. Sankhdher argues that Gandhism is not a systematic position in metaphysics or in political philosophy. Rather, it is a political creed, an economic doctrine, a religious outlook, a moral precept, and especially, a humanitarian world view. It is an effort not to systematize wisdom but to transform society and is based on an undying faith in the goodness of human nature.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> However Gandhi himself did not approve of the notion of "Gandhism", as he explained in 1936:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">There is no such thing as "Gandhism", and I do not want to leave any sect after me. I do not claim to have originated any new principle or doctrine. I have simply tried in my own way to apply the eternal truths to our daily life and problems...The opinions I have formed and the conclusions I have arrived at are not final. I may change them tomorrow. I have nothing new to teach the world. Truth and nonviolence are as old as the hills.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tagore_Gandhi.jpg" title="File:Tagore Gandhi.jpg">File:Tagore Gandhi.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi with famous poet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rabindranath_Tagore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rabindranath Tagore (page does not exist)">Rabindranath Tagore</a>, 1940</div></div></div>
<p>Historian R.B. Cribb argues that Gandhi's thought evolved over time, with his early ideas becoming the core or scaffolding for his mature philosophy. In London he committed himself to truthfulness, temperance, chastity, and vegetarianism. His return to India to work as a lawyer was a failure, so he went to South Africa for a quarter century, where he absorbed ideas from many sources, most of them non-Indian.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> Gandhi grew up in an eclectic religious atmosphere and throughout his life searched for insights from many religious traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> He was exposed to <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jain</a> ideas through his mother who was in contact with Jain monks. Themes from Jainism that Gandhi absorbed included asceticism; compassion for all forms of life; the importance of vows for self-discipline; vegetarianism; fasting for self-purification; mutual tolerance among people of different creeds; and "syadvad", the idea that all views of truth are partial, a doctrine that lies at the root of Satyagraha.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> He received much of his influence from Jainism particularly during his younger years.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's London experience provided a solid philosophical base focused on truthfulness, temperance, chastity, and vegetarianism. When he returned to India in 1891, his outlook was parochial and he could not make a living as a lawyer. This challenged his belief that practicality and morality necessarily coincided. By moving in 1893 to South Africa he found a solution to this problem and developed the central concepts of his mature philosophy.<sup id="cite_ref-Crib1985_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Crib1985-138">[138]</a></sup> N. A. Toothi<sup id="cite_ref-mhe94_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mhe94-139">[139]</a></sup> felt that Gandhi was influenced by the reforms and teachings of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swaminarayan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swaminarayan (page does not exist)">Swaminarayan</a>, stating "Close parallels do exist in programs of social reform based on to nonviolence, truth-telling, cleanliness, temperance and upliftment of the masses."<sup id="cite_ref-rbw01_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rbw01-140">[140]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vallabhbhai_Patel" title="Vallabhbhai Patel">Vallabhbhai Patel</a>, who grew up in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swaminarayan_Sampraday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swaminarayan Sampraday (page does not exist)">Swaminarayan household</a> was attracted to Gandhi due to this aspect of Gandhi's doctrine.<sup id="cite_ref-dalrkr_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dalrkr-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's ethical thinking was heavily influenced by a handful of books, which he repeatedly meditated upon. They included especially <a href="/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Apology_(Plato)" title="Apology (Plato)">Apology</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">John Ruskin</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Unto_this_Last&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unto this Last (page does not exist)">Unto this Last</a></i> (1862) (both of which he translated into his native Gujarati); <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Mackintire_Salter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Mackintire Salter (page does not exist)">William Salter's</a> <i>Ethical Religion</i> (1889); <a href="/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau" title="Henry David Thoreau">Henry David Thoreau</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Civil_Disobedience_(Thoreau)" title="Civil Disobedience (Thoreau)">On the Duty of Civil Disobedience</a></i> (1849); and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leo_Tolstoy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leo Tolstoy (page does not exist)">Leo Tolstoy</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Kingdom_of_God_Is_Within_You" title="The Kingdom of God Is Within You">The Kingdom of God Is Within You</a></i> (1894). Ruskin inspired his decision to live an austere life on a commune, at first on the Phoenix Farm in Natal and then on the Tolstoy Farm just outside Johannesburg, South Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-Parekh2001_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Parekh2001-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Balkrishna Gokhale argues that Gandhi took his philosophy of history from Hinduism and Jainism, supplemented by selected Christian traditions and ideas of Tolstoy and Ruskin. Hinduism provided central concepts of God's role in history, of man as the battleground of forces of virtue and sin, and of the potential of love as an historical force. From Jainism, Gandhi took the idea of applying nonviolence to human situations and the theory that Absolute Reality can be comprehended only relatively in human affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-BGB_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BGB-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historian Howard Spodek argues for the importance of the culture of Gujarat in shaping Gandhi's methods. Spodek finds that some of Gandhi's most effective methods such as fasting, noncooperation and appeals to the justice and compassion of the rulers were learned as a youth in Gujarat. Later on, the financial, cultural, organizational and geographical support needed to bring his campaigns to a national audience were drawn from Ahmedabad and Gujarat, his Indian residence 1915–1930.<sup id="cite_ref-Spodek_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spodek-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tolstoy">Tolstoy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Tolstoy_Farm.jpg" title="File:Gandhi Tolstoy Farm.jpg">File:Gandhi Tolstoy Farm.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mohandas K. Gandhi and other residents of <a href="/wiki/Tolstoyan_movement#Africa" title="Tolstoyan movement">Tolstoy Farm</a>, South Africa, 1910</div></div></div>
<p>Along with the book mentioned above, in 1908 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leo_Tolstoy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leo Tolstoy (page does not exist)">Leo Tolstoy</a> wrote <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Letter_to_a_Hindu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Letter to a Hindu (page does not exist)">A Letter to a Hindu</a>,</i> which said that only by using love as a weapon through <a href="/wiki/Passive_resistance" title="Passive resistance" class="mw-redirect">passive resistance</a> could the Indian people overthrow colonial rule. In 1909, Gandhi wrote to Tolstoy seeking advice and permission to republish <i>A Letter to a Hindu</i> in Gujarati. Tolstoy responded and the two continued a correspondence until Tolstoy's death in 1910 (Tolstoy's last letter was to Gandhi).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> The letters concern practical and theological applications of nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Gandhi saw himself a disciple of Tolstoy, for they agreed regarding opposition to state authority and colonialism; both hated violence and preached non-resistance. However, they differed sharply on political strategy. Gandhi called for political involvement; he was a nationalist and was prepared to use nonviolent force. He was also willing to compromise.<sup id="cite_ref-Green1986_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Green1986-146">[146]</a></sup> It was at Tolstoy Farm where Gandhi and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hermann_Kallenbach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hermann Kallenbach (page does not exist)">Hermann Kallenbach</a> systematically trained their disciples in the philosophy of nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-Bhana_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bhana-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Truth_and_Satyagraha">Truth and Satyagraha</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:God_is_Truth.jpg" title="File:God is Truth.jpg">File:God is Truth.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">"God is truth. The way to truth lies through <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a> (nonviolence)"—<a href="/wiki/Sabarmati_Ashram" title="Sabarmati Ashram">Sabarmati</a> 13 March 1927</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi dedicated his life to the wider purpose of discovering truth, or <i><a href="/wiki/Satya" title="Satya">Satya</a></i>. He tried to achieve this by learning from his own mistakes and conducting experiments on himself. He called his autobiography <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_My_Experiments_with_Truth" title="The Story of My Experiments with Truth">The Story of My Experiments with Truth</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson2006_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson2006-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bruce Watson argues that Gandhi based Satyagraha on the Vedantic ideal of self-realization, and notes it also contains Jain and Buddhist notions of nonviolence, vegetarianism, the avoidance of killing, and 'agape' (universal love). Gandhi also borrowed Christian-Islamic ideas of equality, the brotherhood of man, and the concept of turning the other cheek.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi stated that the most important battle to fight was overcoming his own demons, fears, and insecurities. Gandhi summarised his beliefs first when he said "God is Truth". He would later change this statement to "Truth is God". Thus, <i>satya</i> (truth) in Gandhi's philosophy is "God".<sup id="cite_ref-Parel2006_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Parel2006-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>The essence of <a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">Satyagraha</a> (a name Gandhi invented meaning "adherence to truth"<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>) is that it seeks to eliminate antagonisms without harming the antagonists themselves and seeks to transform or "purify" it to a higher level. A euphemism sometimes used for Satyagraha is that it is a "silent force" or a "soul force" (a term also used by Martin Luther King Jr. during his famous "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Have_a_Dream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Have a Dream (page does not exist)">I Have a Dream</a>" speech). It arms the individual with moral power rather than physical power. Satyagraha is also termed a "universal force", as it essentially "makes no distinction between kinsmen and strangers, young and old, man and woman, friend and foe."<sup id="cite_ref-rules_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rules-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi wrote: "There must be no impatience, no barbarity, no insolence, no undue pressure. If we want to cultivate a true spirit of democracy, we cannot afford to be intolerant. Intolerance betrays want of faith in one's cause."<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Civil_disobedience" title="Civil disobedience">Civil disobedience and noncooperation</a> as practised under Satyagraha are based on the "law of suffering",<sup id="cite_ref-CollectedWorks20_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollectedWorks20-154">[154]</a></sup> a doctrine that <i>the endurance of suffering is a means to an end</i>. This end usually implies a moral upliftment or progress of an individual or society. Therefore, noncooperation in Satyagraha is in fact a means to secure the cooperation of the opponent consistently with <a href="/wiki/Truth" title="Truth">truth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Justice" title="Justice">justice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sharma2008_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharma2008-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nonviolence">Nonviolence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_at_Darwen_with_women.jpg" title="File:Gandhi at Darwen with women.jpg">File:Gandhi at Darwen with women.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gandhi with textile workers at <a href="/wiki/Darwen" title="Darwen">Darwen</a>, Lancashire, 26 September 1931.</div></div></div>
<p>Although Gandhi was not the originator of the principle of nonviolence, he was the first to apply it in the political field on a large scale.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The concept of <a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">nonviolence</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Nonresistance" title="Nonresistance">nonresistance</a> has a long history in Indian religious thought and has had many revivals in Hindu, Buddhist, Jain, Jewish and Christian contexts. Gandhi explains his philosophy and way of life in his autobiography <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_My_Experiments_with_Truth" title="The Story of My Experiments with Truth">The Story of My Experiments with Truth</a></i>. Gandhi realised later that this level of nonviolence required incredible faith and courage, which he believed everyone did not possess. He therefore advised that everyone need not keep to nonviolence, especially if it were used as a cover for cowardice, saying, "where there is only a choice between cowardice and violence, I would advise violence."<sup id="cite_ref-Borman1986_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borman1986-157">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi thus came under some political fire for his criticism of those who attempted to achieve independence through more violent means. His refusal to protest against the hanging of <a href="/wiki/Bhagat_Singh" title="Bhagat Singh">Bhagat Singh</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sukhdev&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sukhdev (page does not exist)">Sukhdev</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Udham_Singh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Udham Singh (page does not exist)">Udham Singh</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rajguru&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rajguru (page does not exist)">Rajguru</a> were sources of condemnation among some parties.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rai_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rai-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of this criticism, Gandhi stated, "There was a time when people listened to me because I showed them how to give fight to the British without arms when they had no arms [...] but today I am told that my nonviolence can be of no avail against the [Hindu–Moslem riots] and, therefore, people should arm themselves for self-defense."<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's views came under heavy criticism in Britain when it was under attack from <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, and later when the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holocaust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holocaust (page does not exist)">Holocaust</a> was revealed. He told the British people in 1940, "I would like you to lay down the arms you have as being useless for saving you or humanity. You will invite Herr Hitler and Signor Mussolini to take what they want of the countries you call your possessions... If these gentlemen choose to occupy your homes, you will vacate them. If they do not give you free passage out, you will allow yourselves, man, woman, and child, to be slaughtered, but you will refuse to owe allegiance to them."<sup id="cite_ref-Wolpert2002_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wolpert2002-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a post-war interview in 1946, he said, "Hitler killed five million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jews&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jews (page does not exist)">Jews</a>. It is the greatest crime of our time. But the Jews should have offered themselves to the butcher's knife. They should have thrown themselves into the sea from cliffs... It would have aroused the world and the people of Germany... As it is they succumbed anyway in their millions."<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> Gandhi believed this act of "collective suicide", in response to the Holocaust, "would have been heroism".<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Muslims">Muslims</span></h4>
<p>One of the Gandhi's major strategies, first in South Africa and then in India, was uniting Muslims and Hindus to work together in opposition to British imperialism. In 1919–22 he won strong Muslim support for his leadership in the <a href="/wiki/Khilafat_Movement" title="Khilafat Movement">Khilafat Movement</a> to support the historic <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">Ottoman Caliphate</a>. By 1924 that Muslim support had largely evaporated.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Jews">Jews</span></h4>
<p>In 1931, he suggested that while he could understand the desire of European Jews to emigrate to Palestine, he opposed any movement that supported <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British colonialism</a> or violence. Muslims throughout India and the Middle East strongly opposed the Zionist plan for a Jewish state in Palestine, and Gandhi (and Congress) supported the Muslims in this regard. By the 1930s all major political groups in India opposed a Jewish state in Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>This led to discussions concerning the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Germany#Jews_under_the_Nazis_.281933.E2.80.931939.29" title="History of the Jews in Germany">persecution of the Jews in Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Aliyah#Zionist_Aliyah_.281882_on.29" title="Aliyah">emigration of Jews from Europe to Palestine</a>, which Gandhi framed through the lens of <a href="/wiki/Satyagraha" title="Satyagraha">Satyagraha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gs_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gs-168">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> In 1937, Gandhi discussed <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a> with his close Jewish friend Hermann Kallenbach.<sup id="cite_ref-dream_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dream-170">[170]</a></sup> He said Zionism was not the right answer to the Jewish problem<sup id="cite_ref-Jack_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jack-171">[171]</a></sup> and instead recommended Satyagraha. Gandhi thought the Zionists in Palestine represented European imperialism and used violence to achieve their goals; he argued that "the Jews should disclaim any intention of realizing their aspiration under the protection of arms and should rely wholly on the goodwill of Arabs. No exception can possibly be taken to the natural desire of the Jews to found a home in Palestine. But they must wait for its fulfillment till Arab opinion is ripe for it."<sup id="cite_ref-gs_168-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gs-168">[168]</a></sup> In 1938, Gandhi stated that his "sympathies are all with the Jews. I have known them intimately in South Africa. Some of them became life-long companions." Philosopher <a href="/wiki/Martin_Buber" title="Martin Buber">Martin Buber</a> was highly critical of Gandhi's approach and in 1939 wrote an open letter to him on the subject. Gandhi reiterated his stance on the use of Satyagraha in Palestine in 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegetarianism_and_food">Vegetarianism and food</span></h3>
<p>Stephen Hay argues that Gandhi in London looked into numerous religious and intellectual currents. He especially appreciated how the <a href="/wiki/Theosophy" title="Theosophy">theosophical movement</a> encouraged a religious eclecticism and an antipathy to atheism. Hay says the vegetarian movement had the greatest impact for it was Gandhi's point of entry into other reformist agendas of the time.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> The idea of vegetarianism is deeply ingrained in Hindu and Jain traditions in India, especially in his native Gujarat.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> Gandhi was close to the chairman of the London Vegetarian Society, Dr. Josiah Oldfield, and corresponded with <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Stephens Salt</a>, a vegetarian campaigner. Gandhi became a strict <a href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarianism" title="Lacto vegetarianism">vegetarian</a>. He wrote the book <i>The Moral Basis of Vegetarianism</i> and wrote for the London Vegetarian Society's publication.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Gandhi was somewhat of a food <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fad (page does not exist)">faddist</a> taking his own goat to travels so he could always have fresh milk.<sup id="cite_ref-Sen2004_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sen2004-176">[176]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi noted in his autobiography that vegetarianism was the beginning of his deep commitment to <a href="/wiki/Brahmacharya" title="Brahmacharya">Brahmacharya</a>; without total control of the palate, his success in Brahmacharya would likely falter. "You wish to know what the marks of a man are who wants to realize Truth which is God", he wrote. "He must reduce himself to zero and have perfect control over all his senses-beginning with the palate or tongue."<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fasting">Fasting</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_and_Indira_1924.jpg" title="File:Gandhi and Indira 1924.jpg">File:Gandhi and Indira 1924.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Fasting, with young <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi" title="Indira Gandhi">Indira Gandhi</a>, mid-1920s</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi used <a href="/wiki/Fasting" title="Fasting">fasting</a> as a political device, often threatening suicide unless demands were met. Congress publicised the fasts as a political action that generated widespread sympathy. In response the government tried to manipulate news coverage to minimise his challenge to the Raj. He fasted in 1932 to protest the voting scheme for separate political representation for Dalits; Gandhi did not want them segregated. The government stopped the London press from showing photographs of his emaciated body, because it would elicit sympathy. Gandhi's 1943 hunger strike took place during a two-year prison term for the anticolonial Quit India movement. The government called on nutritional experts to demystify his action, and again no photos were allowed. However his final fast in 1948, after India was independent, was lauded by the British press and this time did include full-length photos.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alter argues that Gandhi's fixation on diet and celibacy were much deeper than exercises in self-discipline. Rather, his beliefs regarding health offered a critique of both the traditional Hindu system of ayurvedic medicine and Western concepts. This challenge was integral to his deeper challenge to tradition and modernity, as health and nonviolence became part of the same ethics.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Celibacy_and_experiments_with_celibacy_.28Bramhacharya.29">Celibacy and experiments with celibacy (Bramhacharya)</span></h3>
<p>In 1906 Gandhi, although married and a father, vowed to abstain from sexual relations. In the 1940s, in his mid-seventies, he brought his grandniece Manubehn to sleep naked in his bed as part of a spiritual experiment in which Gandhi could test himself as a "brahmachari." Several other young women and girls also sometimes shared his bed as part of his experiments.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Gandhi's behaviour was widely discussed and criticised by family members and leading politicians, including Nehru. Some members of his staff resigned, including two editors of his newspaper who left after refusing to print parts of Gandhi's sermons dealing with his sleeping arrangements. But Gandhi said that if he wouldn't let Manu sleep with him, it would be a sign of weakness.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi discussed his experiment with friends and relations; most disagreed and the experiment ceased in 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
Religious studies scholar Veena Howard argues that Gandhi made "creative use"<sup id="cite_ref-howard2013_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howard2013-184">[184]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> of his celibacy and his authority as a <i>mahatma</i> "to reinterpret religious norms and confront unjust social and religious conventions relegating women to lower status."<sup id="cite_ref-howard2013_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howard2013-184">[184]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
According to Howard, Gandhi "developed his discourse as a religious renouncer within India's traditions to confront repressive social and religious customs regarding women and to bring them into the public sphere, during a time when the discourse on celibacy was typically imbued with masculine rhetoric and misogynist inferences.... his writings show a consistent evolution of his thought toward creating an equal playing field for members of both sexes and even elevating women to a higher plane—all through his discourse and unorthodox practice of <i><a href="/wiki/Brahmacharya" title="Brahmacharya">brahmacharya</a></i>."<sup id="cite_ref-howard2013_184-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howard2013-184">[184]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nai_Talim.2C_basic_education">Nai Talim, basic education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Gandhi's educational policies reflected <i>Nai Talim</i> ('Basic Education for all'), a spiritual principle which states that knowledge and work are not separate. It was a reaction against the British educational system and colonialism in general, which had the negative effect of making Indian children alienated and career-based; it promoted disdain for manual work, the development of a new elite class, and the increasing problems of industrialisation and urbanisation. The three pillars of Gandhi's pedagogy were its focus on the <i>lifelong character</i> of education, its <i>social character</i> and its form as a <i>holistic process</i>. For Gandhi, education is 'the moral development of the person', a process that is by definition 'lifelong'.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nai Talim evolved out of the spiritually oriented education program at Tolstoy Farm in South Africa, and Gandhi's work at the ashram at Sevagram after 1937.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> After 1947 the Nehru government's vision of an industrialised, centrally planned economy had scant place for Gandhi's village-oriented approach.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Swaraj.2C_self-rule">Swaraj, self-rule</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Rudolph argues that after a false start in trying to emulate the English in an attempt to overcome his timidity, Gandhi discovered the inner courage he was seeking by helping his countrymen in South Africa. The new courage consisted of observing the traditional Bengali way of "self-suffering" and, in finding his own courage, he was enabled also to point out the way of 'Satyagraha' and 'ahimsa' to the whole of India.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> Gandhi's writings expressed four meanings of freedom: as India's national independence; as individual political freedom; as group freedom from poverty; and as the capacity for personal self-rule.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi was a self-described <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philosophical_anarchism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philosophical anarchism (page does not exist)">philosophical anarchist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> and his vision of India meant an India without an underlying government.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> He once said that "the ideally nonviolent state would be an ordered anarchy."<sup id="cite_ref-Chakrabarty_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chakrabarty-192">[192]</a></sup> While political systems are largely hierarchical, with each layer of authority from the individual to the central government have increasing levels of authority over the layer below, Gandhi believed that society should be the exact opposite, where nothing is done without the consent of anyone, down to the individual. His idea was that true <a href="/wiki/Swaraj" title="Swaraj">self-rule</a> in a country means that every person rules his or herself and that there is no state which enforces laws upon the people.<sup id="cite_ref-GandhiTolstoy1987_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiTolstoy1987-193">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>This would be achieved over time with nonviolent conflict mediation, as power is divested from layers of hierarchical authorities, ultimately to the individual, which would come to embody the ethic of nonviolence. Rather than a system where rights are enforced by a higher authority, people are self-governed by mutual responsibilities. On returning from South Africa, when Gandhi received a letter asking for his participation in writing a world charter for human rights, he responded saying, "in my experience, it is far more important to have a charter for human duties."<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>A free India did not mean merely transferring the established British administrative structure into Indian hands. He warned, "you would make India English. And when it becomes English, it will be called not Hindustan but Englishtan. This is not the Swaraj I want."<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Tewari argues that Gandhi saw democracy as more than a system of government; it meant promoting both individuality and the self-discipline of the community. Democracy was a moral system that distributed power and assisted the development of every social class, especially the lowest. It meant settling disputes in a nonviolent manner; it required freedom of thought and expression. For Gandhi, democracy was a way of life.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gandhian_economics">Gandhian economics</span></h3>
<p>A free India for Gandhi meant the flourishing of thousands of self-sufficient small communities who rule themselves without hindering others. Gandhian economics focused on the need for economic self-sufficiency at the village level. His policy of "sarvodaya"<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> called for ending poverty through improved agriculture and small-scale cottage industries in every village.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> Gandhi challenged Nehru and the modernizers in the late 1930s who called for rapid industrialisation on the Soviet model; Gandhi denounced that as dehumanising and contrary to the needs of the villages where the great majority of the people lived.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> After Gandhi's death Nehru led India to large-scale planning that emphasised modernisation and heavy industry, while modernising agriculture through irrigation. Historian Kuruvilla <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pandikattu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pandikattu (page does not exist)">Pandikattu</a> says "it was Nehru's vision, not Gandhi's, that was eventually preferred by the Indian State."<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> After Gandhi's death activists inspired by his vision promoted their opposition to industrialisation through the teachings of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhian_economics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhian economics (page does not exist)">Gandhian economics</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Literary_works">Literary works</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Young_India.png" title="File:Young India.png">File:Young India.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Young India</i>, a weekly journal published by Gandhi from 1919 to 1932</div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi was a prolific writer. One of Gandhi's earliest publications, <i>Hind Swaraj</i>, published in Gujarati in 1909, is recognised<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a> as the intellectual blueprint of India's independence movement. The book was translated into English the next year, with a copyright legend that read "No Rights Reserved".<sup id="cite_ref-ie12_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ie12-201">[201]</a></sup> For decades he edited several newspapers including <i><a href="/wiki/Harijan" title="Harijan">Harijan</a></i> in Gujarati, in <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and in the English language; <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Opinion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Opinion (page does not exist)">Indian Opinion</a></i> while in South Africa and, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young India (page does not exist)">Young India</a></i>, in English, and Navajivan, a Gujarati monthly, on his return to India. Later, Navajivan was also published in Hindi. In addition, he wrote letters almost every day to individuals and newspapers.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi also wrote several books including his autobiography, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_My_Experiments_with_Truth" title="The Story of My Experiments with Truth">The Story of My Experiments with Truth</a> (Gujarātī "સત્યના પ્રયોગો અથવા આત્મકથા")</i>, of which he bought the entire first edition to make sure it was reprinted.<sup id="cite_ref-GreatSoulReview_84-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GreatSoulReview-84">[84]</a></sup> His other autobiographies included: <i>Satyagraha in South Africa</i> about his struggle there, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hind_Swaraj_or_Indian_Home_Rule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hind Swaraj or Indian Home Rule (page does not exist)">Hind Swaraj or Indian Home Rule</a></i>, a political pamphlet, and a paraphrase in Gujarati of <a href="/wiki/John_Ruskin" title="John Ruskin">John Ruskin</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Unto_This_Last" title="Unto This Last">Unto This Last</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Unto_this_last_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unto_this_last-203">[203]</a></sup> This last essay can be considered his programme on economics. He also wrote extensively on vegetarianism, diet and health, religion, social reforms, etc. Gandhi usually wrote in Gujarati, though he also revised the Hindi and English translations of his books.<sup id="cite_ref-Pareku_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pareku-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's complete works were published by the Indian government under the name <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=S:The_Collected_Works_of_Mahatma_Gandhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="S:The Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi (page does not exist)">The Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi</a></i> in the 1960s. The writings comprise about 50,000 pages published in about a hundred volumes. In 2000, a revised edition of the complete works sparked a controversy, as it contained a large number of errors and omissions.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> The Indian government later withdrew the revised edition.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_depictions_in_popular_culture">Legacy and depictions in popular culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Graffiti_San_Francisco.jpg" title="File:Gandhi Graffiti San Francisco.jpg">File:Gandhi Graffiti San Francisco.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A wall graffiti in San Francisco containing a quote and image of Gandhi</div></div></div>
<p>The word <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahatma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahatma (page does not exist)">Mahatma</a></i>, while often mistaken for Gandhi's given name in the West, is taken from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanskrit_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanskrit language (page does not exist)">Sanskrit</a> words <i>maha</i> (meaning <i>Great</i>) and <i>atma</i> (meaning <i>Soul</i>). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rabindranath_Tagore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rabindranath Tagore (page does not exist)">Rabindranath Tagore</a> is said to have accorded the title to Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-Tagore1998_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tagore1998-207">[207]</a></sup> In his autobiography, Gandhi nevertheless explains that he never valued the title, and was often pained by it.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Followers_and_international_influence">Followers and international influence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mahatmagandhi.jpg" title="File:Mahatmagandhi.jpg">File:Mahatmagandhi.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Statue" title="Statue">Statue</a> of Mahatma Gandhi at <a href="/wiki/York_University" title="York University">York University</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USSR_stamp_M.Gandi_1969_6k.jpg" title="File:USSR stamp M.Gandi 1969 6k.jpg">File:USSR stamp M.Gandi 1969 6k.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mahatma Gandhi on a 1969 postage stamp of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a></div></div></div>
<p>Gandhi influenced important leaders and political movements. Leaders of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=African-American_Civil_Rights_Movement_(1955%E2%80%931968)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African-American Civil Rights Movement (1955–1968) (page does not exist)">civil rights movement</a> in the United States, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther_King&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther King (page does not exist)">Martin Luther King</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Lawson_(American_activist)" title="James Lawson (American activist)">James Lawson</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bevel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Bevel (page does not exist)">James Bevel</a>, drew from the writings of Gandhi in the development of their own theories about nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> King said "Christ gave us the goals and Mahatma Gandhi the tactics."<sup id="cite_ref-Tougas2011_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tougas2011-214">[214]</a></sup> King sometimes referred to Gandhi as "the little brown saint."<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> Anti-<a href="/wiki/History_of_South_Africa_in_the_Apartheid_Era" title="History of South Africa in the Apartheid Era" class="mw-redirect">apartheid</a> activist and former President of South Africa, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nelson_Mandela&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nelson Mandela (page does not exist)">Nelson Mandela</a>, was inspired by Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-Mandela-2000_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mandela-2000-216">[216]</a></sup> Others include <a href="/wiki/Khan_Abdul_Ghaffar_Khan" title="Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan">Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steve_Biko" title="Steve Biko">Steve Biko</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aung_San_Suu_Kyi" title="Aung San Suu Kyi">Aung San Suu Kyi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his early years, the former <a href="/wiki/President_of_South_Africa" title="President of South Africa">President of South Africa</a> Nelson Mandela was a follower of the nonviolent resistance philosophy of Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-Mandela-2000_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mandela-2000-216">[216]</a></sup> Bhana and Vahed commented on these events as "Gandhi inspired succeeding generations of South African activists seeking to end White rule. This legacy connects him to Nelson Mandela...in a sense Mandela completed what Gandhi started."<sup id="cite_ref-BhanaVahed2005_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BhanaVahed2005-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's life and teachings inspired many who specifically referred to Gandhi as their mentor or who dedicated their lives to spreading Gandhi's ideas. In Europe, <a href="/wiki/Romain_Rolland" title="Romain Rolland">Romain Rolland</a> was the first to discuss Gandhi in his 1924 book <i>Mahatma Gandhi,</i> and Brazilian anarchist and feminist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maria_Lacerda_de_Moura&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maria Lacerda de Moura (page does not exist)">Maria Lacerda de Moura</a> wrote about Gandhi in her work on pacifism. In 1931, notable European physicist <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> exchanged written letters with Gandhi, and called him "a role model for the generations to come" in a letter writing about him.<sup id="cite_ref-Albano-M.C3.BCller_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Albano-M.C3.BCller-219">[219]</a></sup> Einstein said of Gandhi:
</p>
<blockquote>Mahatma Gandhi's life achievement stands unique in political history. He has invented a completely new and humane means for the liberation war of an oppressed country, and practised it with greatest energy and devotion. The moral influence he had on the consciously thinking human being of the entire civilized world will probably be much more lasting than it seems in our time with its overestimation of brutal violent forces. Because lasting will only be the work of such statesmen who wake up and strengthen the moral power of their people through their example and educational works. We may all be happy and grateful that destiny gifted us with such an enlightened contemporary, a role model for the generations to come.</blockquote>
<blockquote>Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this walked the earth in flesh and blood.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> </blockquote>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lanza_del_Vasto" title="Lanza del Vasto">Lanza del Vasto</a> went to India in 1936 intending to live with Gandhi; he later returned to Europe to spread Gandhi's philosophy and founded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Community_of_the_Ark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Community of the Ark (page does not exist)">Community of the Ark</a> in 1948 (modelled after Gandhi's ashrams). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Madeleine_Slade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Madeleine Slade (page does not exist)">Madeleine Slade</a> (known as "Mirabehn") was the daughter of a British admiral who spent much of her adult life in India as a devotee of Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-Dhupelia-Mesthrie2005_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dhupelia-Mesthrie2005-221">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition, the British musician <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a> referred to Gandhi when discussing his views on nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-Rolling_Stone_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rolling_Stone-223">[223]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cannes_Lions_International_Advertising_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival (page does not exist)">Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival</a> in 2007, former US Vice-President and environmentalist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Al_Gore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Al Gore (page does not exist)">Al Gore</a> spoke of Gandhi's influence on him.<sup id="cite_ref-Al_Gore_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al_Gore-224">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> in a 2010 address to the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">Parliament of India</a> said that:
</p>
<blockquote>I am mindful that I might not be standing before you today, as President of the United States, had it not been for Gandhi and the message he shared with America and the world.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup></blockquote> Obama in September 2009 said that his biggest inspiration came from Mahatma Gandhi. His reply was in response to the question 'Who was the one person, dead or live, that you would choose to dine with?'. He continued that "He's somebody I find a lot of inspiration in. He inspired Dr. King with his message of nonviolence. He ended up doing so much and changed the world just by the power of his ethics."<sup id="cite_ref-Wakefield_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wakefield-226">[226]</a></sup>
<p><i>Time Magazine</i> named <a href="/w/index.php?title=14th_Dalai_Lama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="14th Dalai Lama (page does not exist)">The 14th Dalai Lama</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lech_Wa%C5%82%C4%99sa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lech Wałęsa (page does not exist)">Lech Wałęsa</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther_King&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther King (page does not exist)">Martin Luther King</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cesar_Chavez" title="Cesar Chavez">Cesar Chavez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aung_San_Suu_Kyi" title="Aung San Suu Kyi">Aung San Suu Kyi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benigno_Aquino,_Jr." title="Benigno Aquino, Jr.">Benigno Aquino, Jr.</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Desmond_Tutu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Desmond Tutu (page does not exist)">Desmond Tutu</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nelson_Mandela&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nelson Mandela (page does not exist)">Nelson Mandela</a> as <i>Children of Gandhi</i> and his spiritual heirs to nonviolence.<sup id="cite_ref-TimeTCOG_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TimeTCOG-227">[227]</a></sup>
The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahatma_Gandhi_District&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahatma Gandhi District (page does not exist)">Mahatma Gandhi District</a> in <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a>, Texas, United States, an ethnic Indian enclave, is officially named after Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-MorenoCelebrates_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MorenoCelebrates-228">[228]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_holidays">Global holidays</span></h3>
<p>In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a> declared Gandhi's birthday 2 October as "the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Day_of_Non-Violence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Day of Non-Violence (page does not exist)">International Day of Nonviolence</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-UN_declares_2_October.2C_Gandhi.E2.80.99s_birthday.2C_as_International_Day_of_Nonviolence_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_declares_2_October.2C_Gandhi.E2.80.99s_birthday.2C_as_International_Day_of_Nonviolence-229">[229]</a></sup> First proposed by UNESCO in 1948, as the School Day of Nonviolence and Peace (DENIP in Spanish),<sup id="cite_ref-cartadelapaz_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cartadelapaz-230">[230]</a></sup> 30 January is observed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=School_Day_of_Non-violence_and_Peace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="School Day of Non-violence and Peace (page does not exist)">School Day of Nonviolence and Peace</a> in schools of many countries<sup id="cite_ref-DENIP_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DENIP-231">[231]</a></sup> In countries with a Southern Hemisphere school calendar, it is observed on 30 March.<sup id="cite_ref-DENIP_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DENIP-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandi_bista_Novi_Beograd.JPG" title="File:Gandi bista Novi Beograd.JPG">File:Gandi bista Novi Beograd.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Monument to M.K. Gandhi in <a href="/wiki/New_Belgrade" title="New Belgrade" class="mw-redirect">New Belgrade</a>, Serbia. On the monument is written "Nonviolence is the essence of all religions".</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time magazine</a></i> named Gandhi the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Magazine_Person_of_the_Year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Magazine Person of the Year (page does not exist)">Man of the Year</a> in 1930. Gandhi was also the runner-up to <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Person_of_the_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Person of the Century (page does not exist)">Person of the Century</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> at the end of 1999. The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> awards the annual <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Peace_Prize" title="Gandhi Peace Prize">Gandhi Peace Prize</a> to distinguished social workers, world leaders and citizens. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nelson_Mandela&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nelson Mandela (page does not exist)">Nelson Mandela</a>, the leader of South Africa's struggle to eradicate racial discrimination and segregation, is a prominent non-Indian recipient. In 2011, <i>Time</i> magazine named Gandhi as one of the top 25 political icons of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi did not receive the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Peace_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Peace Prize (page does not exist)">Nobel Peace Prize</a>, although he was nominated five times between 1937 and 1948, including the first-ever nomination by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Friends_Service_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Friends Service Committee (page does not exist)">American Friends Service Committee</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-AFSC_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFSC-234">[234]</a></sup> though he made the short list only twice, in 1937 and 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-T.C3.B8nnesson_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T.C3.B8nnesson-114">[114]</a></sup> Decades later, the Nobel Committee publicly declared its regret for the omission, and admitted to deeply divided nationalistic opinion denying the award.<sup id="cite_ref-T.C3.B8nnesson_114-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T.C3.B8nnesson-114">[114]</a></sup> Gandhi was nominated in 1948 but was assassinated before nominations closed. That year, the committee chose not to award the peace prize stating that "there was no suitable living candidate" and later research shows that the possibility of awarding the prize posthumously to Gandhi was discussed and that the reference to no suitable living candidate was to Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-T.C3.B8nnesson_114-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T.C3.B8nnesson-114">[114]</a></sup> When the <a href="/w/index.php?title=14th_Dalai_Lama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="14th Dalai Lama (page does not exist)">14th Dalai Lama</a> was awarded the Prize in 1989, the chairman of the committee said that this was "in part a tribute to the memory of Mahatma Gandhi."<sup id="cite_ref-T.C3.B8nnesson_114-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T.C3.B8nnesson-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_Farm_Animals.27_Day">World Farm Animals' Day</span></h3>
<p>Gandhi's birthday is chosen as a commemoration for the billions of non-human animals that are slaughtered by the human farming industry each year. The practice started in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-HandelmanSchein1990_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HandelmanSchein1990-235">[235]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film_and_literature">Film and literature</span></h3>
<p>Mahatma Gandhi has been portrayed in film, literature, and in the theatre. <a href="/wiki/Ben_Kingsley" title="Ben Kingsley">Ben Kingsley</a> portrayed him in the 1982 film <i><a href="/wiki/Gandhi_(film)" title="Gandhi (film)">Gandhi</a></i>, which won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Academy Award</a> for Best Picture. Gandhi was a central figure in the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> comedy film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lage_Raho_Munna_Bhai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lage Raho Munna Bhai (page does not exist)">Lage Raho Munna Bhai</a></i>. The 1996 film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Making_of_the_Mahatma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Making of the Mahatma (page does not exist)">The Making of the Mahatma</a></i> documented Gandhi's time in South Africa and his transformation from an inexperienced barrister to recognised political leader.<sup id="cite_ref-Making_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Making-236">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>Anti-Gandhi themes have also been showcased through films and plays. The 1995 Marathi play <i>Gandhi Virudh Gandhi</i> explored the relationship between Gandhi and his son Harilal. The 2007 film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhi,_My_Father&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhi, My Father (page does not exist)">Gandhi, My Father</a></i> was inspired on the same theme. The 1989 Marathi play <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Me_Nathuram_Godse_Boltoy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Me Nathuram Godse Boltoy (page does not exist)">Me Nathuram Godse Boltoy</a></i> and the 1997 Hindi play <i>Gandhi Ambedkar</i> criticised Gandhi and his principles.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several biographers have undertaken the task of describing Gandhi's life. Among them are D. G. Tendulkar with his <i>Mahatma. Life of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi</i> in eight volumes, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pyarelal_Nayyar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pyarelal Nayyar (page does not exist)">Pyarelal</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sushila_Nayyar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sushila Nayyar (page does not exist)">Sushila Nayyar</a> with their <i>Mahatma Gandhi</i> in 10 volumes. There is another documentary, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahatma:_Life_of_Gandhi,_1869%E2%80%931948&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahatma: Life of Gandhi, 1869–1948 (page does not exist)">Mahatma: Life of Gandhi, 1869–1948</a></i>, which is 14 chapters and six hours long.<sup id="cite_ref-IMDB-ahatmaLOG_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMDB-ahatmaLOG-239">[239]</a></sup> The 2010 biography, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Soul:_Mahatma_Gandhi_and_His_Struggle_With_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India (page does not exist)">Great Soul: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Lelyveld" title="Joseph Lelyveld">Joseph Lelyveld</a> contained controversial material speculating about Gandhi's sexual life.<sup id="cite_ref-LelyveldNYT_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LelyveldNYT-240">[240]</a></sup> Lelyveld, however, stated that the press coverage "grossly distort[s]" the overall message of the book.<sup id="cite_ref-LelyveldResponse_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LelyveldResponse-241">[241]</a></sup> The 2014 film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Welcome_Back_Gandhi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welcome Back Gandhi (page does not exist)">Welcome Back Gandhi</a></i> takes a fictionalized look at how Gandhi might react to modern day India.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Current_impact_within_India">Current impact within India</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_Memorial_Kanyakumari.jpg" title="File:Gandhi Memorial Kanyakumari.jpg">File:Gandhi Memorial Kanyakumari.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhi_Mandapam_(Chennai)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhi Mandapam (Chennai) (page does not exist)">The Gandhi Mandapam</a>, a temple in <a href="/wiki/Kanyakumari" title="Kanyakumari">Kanyakumari</a>, Tamil Nadu in India. This temple was erected to honour M.K. Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-Gandhi_Mandapam_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gandhi_Mandapam-243">[243]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>India, with its rapid economic modernisation and urbanisation, has rejected <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gandhian_economics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gandhian economics (page does not exist)">Gandhi's economics</a><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> but accepted much of his politics and continues to revere his memory. Reporter Jim Yardley notes that, "modern India is hardly a Gandhian nation, if it ever was one. His vision of a village-dominated economy was shunted aside during his lifetime as rural romanticism, and his call for a national ethos of personal austerity and nonviolence has proved antithetical to the goals of an aspiring economic and military power." By contrast Gandhi is "given full credit for India's political identity as a tolerant, secular democracy."<sup id="cite_ref-Obama_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Obama-245">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gandhi's birthday, 2 October, is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_holiday_in_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National holiday in India (page does not exist)">national holiday in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gandhi_Jayanti" title="Gandhi Jayanti">Gandhi Jayanti</a>. Gandhi's image also appears on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahatma_Gandhi_Series_(banknotes)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahatma Gandhi Series (banknotes) (page does not exist)">paper currency of all denominations</a> issued by <a href="/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_India" title="Reserve Bank of India">Reserve Bank of India</a>, except for the one rupee note.<sup id="cite_ref-rbi_notes_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rbi_notes-246">[246]</a></sup> Gandhi's date of death, 30 January, is commemorated as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martyrs%27_Day_(India)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martyrs' Day (India) (page does not exist)">Martyrs' Day</a> in India.<sup id="cite_ref-MDay_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MDay-247">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are two temples in India dedicated to Gandhi.<sup id="cite_ref-GandhiGod_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiGod-248">[248]</a></sup> One is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sambalpur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sambalpur (page does not exist)">Sambalpur</a> in Orissa and the other at Nidaghatta village near Kadur in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chikmagalur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chikmagalur (page does not exist)">Chikmagalur</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Karnataka" title="Karnataka">Karnataka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GandhiGod_248-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiGod-248">[248]</a></sup> The Gandhi Memorial in <a href="/wiki/Kanyakumari" title="Kanyakumari">Kanyakumari</a> resembles central Indian Hindu temples and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tamukkam_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tamukkam Palace (page does not exist)">Tamukkam or Summer Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a> now houses the Mahatma Gandhi Museum.<sup id="cite_ref-AbramEdwards2003_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AbramEdwards2003-249">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
